title: Why was comedian Don Rickles so respected by his peers and fans despite his cruel and capricious persona? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rickles’ humor was different and on the shocking side for his time. He was an equal-opportunity insulter and (in my memory) didn’t single out people for gender, race, etc. and was never really cruel. He didn’t “punch down,” he punched everyone. But there wasn’t any nastiness or real hostility there. It was just a quick-witted ability to puncture vanity or satirize. And from all accounts, that was an act that didn’t carry over into real life. His lifelong BF Bob Newhart said, “ . . . he was one of the kindest, caring and most sensitive human beings we have ever known.” After his death at 91 there were countless tributes from many people in show biz acknowledging his influence and talent.

Because after his act was over, people knew what it was, an act. Don was the true example of a gentleman in real life. In his Las Vegas act for instance, after he had given a person a bad time, he made sure to talk to them after the show, and even comped their table a bottle of champagne for being “part of the act.” As for his peers, offstage, he was nothing but supportive, even while busting their chops. It takes a true talent to be a friend of Frank Sinatra’s while telling him onstage, “Make yourself at home Frank, hit somebody!”
